p: The morbidity and mortality of lung cancer has been the highest among all types of cancers, so it is the most common form of malignancy worldwide [ 1]. Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) is a major pathological subtype of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which approximately accounts for 40% of lung cancer cases [ 2]. Surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and targeted therapy are the conventional methods of treating patients with NSCLC; however, the prognosis of these patients has been unsatisfactory till date [ 3]. Since the past decade, immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIS) have been used to treat patients with NSCLC, and they have modified the treatment pattern of this refractory disease [ 4]. Tumor-infiltrating immune cells (TIICs) have impacted the immune system and tackled abnormal biological behaviors in a complex way, so they play a key role in eliciting the bodyâ€™s response to immunotherapy [ 5].
